javabikes

Class Booking

  • java.lang.Object
    • javabikes.Booking

  • public class Booking
extends java.lang.Object
    Main class of the program. This class guides the whole user interaction with the system, and it calls constructors and methods from other classes when it is needed.

    • Method Detail

      • askLastConfirm

        public static void askLastConfirm(java.lang.String name,
                                  java.lang.String lastNumbers,
                                  int price)
        This method is executed right before charging the user's credit card. It asks the user for an active confirm of his/her previous choices: it displays the last four numbers of the user's credit card and the price of the selected bike. If the user confirms the choice, the booking will be completed, unless exceptions occur during the payment. The input can be:
        • "quit": input accepted, the program will abort the current booking and will terminate.
        • any other input: accepted, the user confirmed the previous choices and his/her credit card will be charged.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the customer.
        lastNumbers - last four digits of the customer's credit card.
        price - price of the bike chosen by the customer.

      • bikeBrowser

        public static void bikeBrowser(java.util.ArrayList<?> arrayBikes)
        This method is called after the user chose between normal bikes and electric bikes. Depending on the selectType() result, it will call the printBikes() method only with the arrayBikes parameter, or it will overload that method with the result of whichType(). For more details on selectType(), printBikes() and whichType() methods, see their detailed description.
        Parameters:
        arrayBikes - an ArrayList of generic objects: it uses the ? notation, so any ArrayList is accepted. This is done in order to be able to pass to this method both an ArrayList of Bike objects and an ArrayList of ElectricBike objects.

      • chooseIfElectric

        public static java.lang.Boolean chooseIfElectric()
        This methods asks the user if he/she wants an electric bike or a normal bike.

        The input can be:
        • "1": input accepted, the customer chose to see electric bikes.
        • "2": input accepted, the customer chose to see normal bikes.
        • "quit": input accepted, it will lead to the execution of the second case statement in the switch block.
        • any other input: not accepted, the user will have to re-enter something


        This method returns true or false, depending on the user's wishes. It can also terminate the program, if the user wants to.
        Returns:
        Boolean a Boolean value, that is true if the user wants to see electric bikes, it is false if the user wants to see normal bikes.

      • confirmed

        public static java.lang.Boolean confirmed()
        This methods asks the user if he/she wants to confirm the choice, or if he/she wants to browse the bikes' database again. It returns true or false, depending on the user's wishes. It can also terminate the program, if the user wants so.

        The input can be:
        • "yes": input accepted, the method will return true.
        • "quit": input accepted, the program will exit.
        • "no": input accepted, the method will return false and the user will browse the bikes' database again.


        Returns:
        Boolean a Boolean value, that is true if the user wants to continue to browse the bikes' catalog, otherwise it will be false.

      • getBikes

        public static java.util.ArrayList<Bike> getBikes()
                                          throws java.io.IOException
        This method loads the bike's database into an ArrayList of Bike objects. The bike's database is a comma-delimited text file.

        ArrayList is used since it can have a variable length: an Array has a fixed length, and it would lead to bugs if the amount of bikes in the database changes over time.

        When it is executed, it checks the current working directory (the root directory of the project) and it appends to that "/javabikes/bikes.txt": "/javabikes" is the folder/package in which the "bikes.txt" database file is located. This is needed in order to allow the project to be exported and imported on different machines, without having to remap the path to the database file.

        Once the file is located, a BufferedReader object is created, called reader. A while loop goes through each line of the reader, and it stops only when it finds a blank line: there are no more bikes, the database is completely loaded.

        Each line of the database is split into an Array of strings, and then those values are passed to the Bike's constructor: a Bike object called newBike is created. newBike is then added to the ArrayList, through the add(newBike) method.
        Returns:
        arrayBikes ArrayList of Bike objects.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • getElectricBikes

        public static java.util.ArrayList<ElectricBike> getElectricBikes()
                                                          throws java.io.IOException
        This method loads the electric bike's database into an ArrayList of ElectricBike objects. The bike's database is a comma-delimited text file.

        This method is almost the same as getBikes(), with just minor differences due to the different types of object that it deals with.

        ArrayList is used since it can have a variable length: an Array has a fixed length, and it would lead to bugs if the amount of electric bikes in the database changes over time.

        When it is executed, it checks the current working directory (the root directory of the project) and it appends to that "/javabikes/electricbikes.txt": "/javabikes" is the folder/package in which the "electricbikes.txt" database file is located. This is needed in order to allow the project to be exported and imported on different machines, without having to remap the path to the database file.

        Once the file is located, a BufferedReader object is created, called reader. A while loop goes through each line of the reader, and it stops only when it finds a blank line: there are no more electric bikes, the database is completely loaded.

        Each line of the database is split into an Array of strings, and then those values are passed to the ElectricBike's constructor: a ElectricBike object called newBike is created. newBike is then added to the ArrayList, through the add(newBike) method.
        Returns:
        arrayBikes ArrayList of ElectricBike objects.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
                 throws java.io.IOException
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • printBikes

        public static void printBikes(java.util.ArrayList<?> arrayBikes)
        This methods prints out a table with the available bikes.

        It receives an ArrayList of generic objects, it checks if those objects belong to the ElectricBike class or not. If they do, it will print the ID, color, price, bike type, battery level and km range for each bike, only if the bike is available.

        If the ArrayList is made of normal bikes, it will act as above, except that it will not print the two last columns (battery level and km range), since a normal bike has no battery (and no km range).
        Parameters:
        arrayBikes - an ArrayList of generic objects: it uses the ? notation, so any ArrayList is accepted. This is done in order to be able to pass to this method both an ArrayList of Bike objects and an ArrayList of ElectricBike objects.

      • printBikes

        public static void printBikes(java.util.ArrayList<?> arrayBikes,
                              java.lang.String bikeType)
        Overloads the printBikes(arrayBikes) method; it does so by specifying an additional parameter: a String called bikeType. It acts almost exactly as printBikes(arrayBikes), but it prints out only the bikes of the specified bikeType.

        This method receives an ArrayList of generic objects, it checks if those objects belong to the ElectricBike class or not. If they do, it will print the ID, color, price, bike type, battery level and km range for each bike, only if the bike is available and if it is of the correct type (men's, women's or kids' bike).

        If the ArrayList is made of normal bikes, it will act as above, except that it will not print the two last columns (battery level and km range), since a normal bike has no battery (and no km range).
        Parameters:
        arrayBikes - an ArrayList of generic objects: it uses the ? notation, so any ArrayList is accepted. This is done in order to be able to pass to this method both an ArrayList of Bike objects and an ArrayList of ElectricBike objects.
        bikeType - a String that describes the bikeType that the user wants to see. It can be "m", "w" or "k".

      • selectBike

        public static int selectBike(java.util.ArrayList<?> arrayBikes)
        This method is called when the user wants to select a bike.

        The user has to enter the identification number (ID) of the chosen bike. The input must satisfy three conditions: it has to be an Integer, it can't be bigger than the size of the ArrayList of bikes and it must be the ID of a bike that is available.

        • If the input is not an Integer, a InputMismatchException is raised and caught; the user will receive a warning message that reminds him/her that the input must be a number.
        • If the input is a number higher than the size of the ArrayList of bikes, a IndexOutOfBoundsException is raised and caught; the user will receive a warning message that tells him/her that the entered input is too high.
        • If the input is a valid ID, but it is the ID of a bike that is not available, a generic Exception is raised and caught, and the user will be warned that the chosen bike is not available.


        Each time an exception is thrown and caught, the do-while loop will restart, because the inputOk variable is not set to true; this variable will be true if and only if all the three conditions on the input are satisfied. When this happens, !inputOk will evaluate to false, and the loop will end.
        Parameters:
        arrayBikes - an ArrayList of generic objects: it uses the ? notation, so any ArrayList is accepted. This is done in order to be able to pass to this method both an ArrayList of Bike objects and an ArrayList of ElectricBike objects.
        Returns:
        ID an Integer representing the identification code of the bike that the user selected.

      • selectType

        public static java.lang.Boolean selectType()
        This methods asks the user if he/she wants to browse a specific bike type (men's, women's or kids' bikes), or if he/she wants to browse all bikes.

        The input can be:
        • "1": input accepted, the customer wants to see all available bikes; the method will return false.
        • "2": input accepted, the customer wants to select a bike type; the method will return true.
        • any other input: not accepted, the user will have to re-enter something


        This method returns true or false, depending on the user's wishes.
        Returns:
        Boolean a Boolean value, that is true if the user wants to select a bike type and that is false if the user wants to see all available bikes.

      • updateBikeDatabase

        public static void updateBikeDatabase(java.lang.Boolean electricOrNot,
                                      int bikeID)
                               throws java.io.IOException
        Updates the bikes' database, by removing the bike that the customer just booked. This methods checks whether the customer booked a normal bike or an electric bike, and selects the appropriate database ("bikes.txt" or "electricbikes.txt"). It then proceeds to update the chosen database.

        Since it is not possible to change a single value in a single line of a text file, the only way to update the bikes' database is the following:
        • Create a new temporary file.
        • Copy the content of the old file into the temporary file, line by line
        • When the line with the booked bike is about to be copied, the lineNumber == bikeID boolean expression will evaluate to true, and that single line will be modified, through the replace(oldString, newString) method. This method will replace "true" with "false", removing the bike from the available bikes
        • The lines after the one with the booked bike are copied without modifications.
        • The old file is deleted.
        • The temporary file is renamed, with the same name as the old file; this is needed because when the program will restart, it will load bikes from "bikes.txt" or from "electricbikes.txt", and if it can't find one of those two files it will terminate.
        Parameters:
        electricOrNot - a Boolean value, it is true if the customer booked an electric bike, otherwise it is false.
        bikeID - the identification number of the booked bike.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • whichType

        public static java.lang.String whichType()
        This methods asks the user which type of bikes he/she wants to see.

        The input can be:
        • "m": input accepted, the customer wants to see men's bikes.
        • "w": input accepted, the customer wants to see women's bikes.
        • "k": input accepted, the customer wants to see kids' bikes.
        • any other input: not accepted, the user will have to re-enter something


        This method returns the customer's choice ("m", "w" or "k"); basically, it is needed only to sanitize the user's input, to prevent unhandled exceptions to occur.
        Returns:
        choice a String, it can be "m" or "w" or "k", depending on the user's wishes.
